skill: Student can place equivalent fractions on dual stacked number lines with scaffolding
problem_type: Student places two equivalent fractions on stacked number lines, one fraction at a time with guidance
workspace_description: Two horizontal number lines stacked vertically. Top line partitioned for first fraction's denominator, bottom line partitioned for second fraction's denominator. Both lines show 0 and 1 labels only. Vertical alignment visible between lines.
prompt_examples: Place 1/3 on the top line, then place 2/6 on the bottom line.
First place 1/2 on the top line. Then place 2/4 on the bottom line.
Place 2/3 on the top line, then find where 4/6 goes on the bottom line.
action_description: Student clicks tick mark on top line to place first fraction, then clicks tick mark on bottom line to place equivalent fraction
correct_end_state: Points placed at equivalent positions on both lines, aligned vertically
success_dialogue: Both fractions land at the same position.
Right. They line up vertically.
Good. Same position means equivalent.
That's it. One point above the other.

skill: Student can independently place equivalent fractions on dual stacked number lines
problem_type: Student places two equivalent fractions simultaneously on stacked number lines
workspace_description: Two horizontal number lines stacked vertically. Top line partitioned for first fraction's denominator, bottom line partitioned for second fraction's denominator. Both lines show 0 and 1 labels only.
prompt_examples: Place 1/2 and 2/4 on the number lines to show they're equivalent.
Show that 2/3 equals 4/6. Place both fractions.
Place 3/6 and 1/2 at the same position.
action_description: Student clicks tick marks on both lines to place two points that align vertically
correct_end_state: Two points placed at equivalent positions, aligned vertically between the two lines
success_dialogue: Equivalent fractions at the same position.
Right. Both land at the same spot.
Good work. They line up perfectly.
Correct. Same position proves equivalence.

skill: Student can place fractions equal to 1 (b/b) on number line
problem_type: Student clicks position where b/b fraction lands on 0-1 or 0-2 number line
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 1 (or 0 to 2 for context). Line is partitioned for the fraction's denominator. Labels show 0 and endpoint only.
prompt_examples: Place 4/4 on the number line.
Where does 6/6 land? Place a point.
Find where 8/8 goes on the line.
Place 5/5 at its position.
action_description: Student clicks the tick mark at position 1 to place the fraction
correct_end_state: Point placed at position 1 on the number line
success_dialogue: Right. 4/4 equals 1.
That's it. All parts equal one whole.
Correct. 6/6 lands at 1.
Good. When numerator equals denominator, the fraction equals 1.

skill: Student can place fractions equal to 2 (2b/b) on extended number line
problem_type: Student clicks position where fraction equal to 2 lands on 0-3 number line
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 3. Line is partitioned for the fraction's denominator. Labels show 0, 1, 2, and 3.
prompt_examples: Place 8/4 on the number line.
Where does 6/3 land? Place a point.
Find where 10/5 goes on the line.
Place 8/4. It equals 2.
action_description: Student clicks the tick mark at position 2 to place the fraction
correct_end_state: Point placed at position 2 on the number line
success_dialogue: Right. 8/4 equals 2.
That's it. Two complete wholes.
Correct. 6/3 lands at 2.
Good. Eight fourths is two wholes.

skill: Student can place fractions with denominator 1 (n/1) on number line
problem_type: Student clicks position where n/1 fraction lands on 0-4 number line
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 4. No tick marks shown (whole units only). Labels show 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4.
prompt_examples: Place 2/1 on the number line.
Where does 3/1 land? Place a point.
Find where 4/1 goes on the line.
Place 1/1 at its position.
action_description: Student clicks the whole number position matching the numerator
correct_end_state: Point placed at position n (where n is the numerator) on the number line
success_dialogue: Right. 2/1 equals 2.
That's it. One whole-sized piece lands there.
Correct. 3/1 equals 3.
Good. When denominator is 1, the fraction equals the numerator.

skill: Student can identify which fraction is equivalent to target fraction
problem_type: Student selects one fraction from multiple choices that equals the target
workspace_description: Multiple choice display with 4 fraction options. Optional: two stacked number lines showing target fraction position (visual support for support/baseline tier).
prompt_examples: Which fraction equals 1/2? Select one.
Click the fraction equivalent to 2/3.
Which one equals 1/4?
action_description: Student clicks one option from the multiple choice list
success_dialogue: Right. They're equivalent.
Correct. Same position, same value.
That's it. They equal the same amount.
Good. Those fractions are equivalent.

skill: Student can identify all fractions equivalent to target from a list
problem_type: Student selects all fractions that equal the target (multiple correct answers)
workspace_description: Multiple choice display with 5-6 fraction options, allowing multiple selections. Optional: number lines showing target position (visual support for baseline tier).
prompt_examples: Click all fractions that equal 1/2. You can choose more than one.
Select every fraction equivalent to 1/3.
Find all the fractions that equal 2/4.
action_description: Student clicks multiple options from the list to select all equivalents
correct_end_state: All equivalent fractions selected, no incorrect selections
success_dialogue: Right. All of those equal the target.
Correct. You found all the equivalents.
Good work. Those all land at the same position.
That's it. All equivalent to the target.

skill: Student can recognize patterns for when fractions equal whole numbers
workspace_description: Multiple choice display with 3-4 statements about fraction patterns. Allow multiple selections.
prompt_examples: Click all true statements about fractions that equal whole numbers.
Which patterns help you know when a fraction equals 1 or 2?
Select the rules that are true.
action_description: Student clicks statements that correctly describe whole number patterns

correct_patterns: When numerator equals denominator, fraction equals 1
When numerator is double denominator, fraction equals 2
When denominator is 1, fraction equals the numerator
distractor_patterns: You always add numerator and denominator
The fraction always equals the numerator
parameter_coverage.option_note: Use patterns that are clearly always true (correct) or clearly always false (distractors). Avoid statements that are sometimes true

correct_end_state: All correct pattern statements selected, no incorrect selections
success_dialogue: Right. Those patterns work.
Correct. Numerator and denominator relationship tells us.
Good thinking. You identified the patterns.
That's it. Those rules help identify whole numbers.

skill: Student can identify which fraction from a bank labels a given position
problem_type: Student drags correct fraction label to mark position on bottom line that matches top line fraction
workspace_description: Two stacked number lines. Top line shows a fraction at a marked position. Bottom line has a marked position (unlabeled) at the same spot. Fraction bank with 4-5 options available for dragging.
prompt_examples: The top line shows 3/2. Drag the equivalent fraction to label the bottom line.
Label the marked position on the bottom line. It should equal 1/2.
Drag the fraction that equals 2/3 to the marked spot.
action_description: Student drags one fraction label from the bank to the marked position on the bottom number line
correct_end_state: Correct equivalent fraction label placed at the marked position on bottom line
success_dialogue: Right. Same position, equivalent fractions.
Correct. 6/4 equals 3/2.
Good. You found the equivalent.
That's it. They land at the same spot.

skill: Student can identify equivalent fractions across different visual representations
problem_type: Student multi-selects all models (bars and number lines) that show fractions equivalent to target
workspace_description: 1 reference model shown at top (bar or number line with labeled point). 3 option models below: mix of FracShape bars (with shading) and NumLine segments (with labeled points). All bars same total size, all lines 0-1 range. Multi-select interface on the 3 options. CONSTRAINT: No exact duplicate of reference (e.g., if reference is 1/2 shaded bar, options cannot include another 1/2 shaded bar, but CAN include 2/4 or 3/6 shaded bars, or 1/2 labeled point on number line).
prompt_examples: Which models show fractions equivalent to 1/4? Click all that apply.
Find all the models equal to 1/2. Select all correct ones.
Some are bars, some are lines. Which show 2/3?
Click every model that equals 1/3.
action_description: Student clicks multiple models from the 3 options to select all showing target or equivalent fractions

line_representations: Same fractions as labeled points on 0-1 number lines
distractors: Non-equivalent bars and lines with different fractions
parameter_coverage.constraint_note: Options must differ from reference in representation type or fraction value (not both identical)

correct_end_state: All option models showing reference fraction or equivalents selected; no incorrect selections
success_dialogue: Right. You found all the equivalents.
Correct. Same fraction in different models.
Yes. Bars and lines both show equivalence.
Good eye. You recognized it across representations.

skill: Student can place equivalent fractions greater than 1 on extended dual number lines
problem_type: Student places two equivalent fractions (both > 1) on stacked 0-3 number lines
workspace_description: Two horizontal number lines stacked vertically, ranging from 0 to 3. Top line partitioned for first fraction's denominator, bottom line partitioned for second fraction's denominator. Labels show 0, 1, 2, and 3.
prompt_examples: Place 3/2 on the top line and 6/4 on the bottom line.
Show that 5/4 equals 10/8. Place both fractions.
Place 4/3 and 8/6 to show they're equivalent.
action_description: Student clicks tick marks on both lines to place two points beyond position 1 that align vertically
correct_end_state: Two points placed beyond position 1, aligned vertically at equivalent positions
success_dialogue: Right. Both fractions land past 1 at the same position.
Correct. Same position even beyond 1.
Good. Equivalence works for fractions greater than 1 too.
That's it. They line up at the same spot.

skill: Student can identify where a fraction greater than 1 lands on number line
problem_type: Student selects correct position where fraction > 1 lands (from choices 1, 2, 3, or between)
workspace_description: Multiple choice display with position options. Optional: number line visual showing range 0-3 for reference.
prompt_examples: Where does 8/4 land on the number line? Select one.
Click the position where 6/3 goes.
Where does 5/2 land?
action_description: Student clicks one position option from the multiple choice list
correct_end_state: Correct position selected for the given fraction
success_dialogue: Right. 8/4 equals 2.
Correct. That fraction reaches 2.
Good. Two complete wholes.
That's it. The fraction lands at 2.

skill: Student can identify all fractions equivalent to target without visual number line support
problem_type: Student selects all fractions from list that equal target (abstract reasoning, no visual)
workspace_description: Multiple choice display with 6-8 fraction options. NO visual number line or bars shown - pure notation reasoning.
prompt_examples: Click all fractions that equal 1/2. No number line this time.
Find every fraction equivalent to 1. You can choose more than one.
Select all fractions that equal 2/3.
action_description: Student clicks multiple fraction options to select all that are equivalent to the target
correct_end_state: All correct equivalents selected, no incorrect selections
success_dialogue: Right. All of those are equivalent.
Correct. You reasoned through it without the visual.
Good thinking. Abstract equivalence reasoning.
That's it. You found all the equivalents.

skill: Student can identify which pairs of fractions are equivalent
problem_type: Student multi-selects pairs from a list that show equivalent fractions (notation format, no visuals)
workspace_description: List of 4-6 fraction pairs displayed as notation (e.g., '1/2, 2/4'). No visual bars or number lines - pure notation. Multi-select interface allows clicking multiple pairs.
prompt_examples: Which pairs show equivalent fractions? Click all that apply.
Select every pair where both fractions are equal.
Find the pairs that are equivalent.
Click all pairs that show the same amount.
action_description: Student clicks multiple pairs to select all that are internally equivalent
correct_end_state: All equivalent pairs selected; no non-equivalent pairs selected
success_dialogue: Right. 1/2 and 2/4 are equivalent.
Correct. You found the equivalent pairs.
Yes. Those pairs show equivalence.
Good. All of those pairs are equal.
